title: 115_hr1867
content: The "Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act" allows certain Alaska Native veterans to apply for land allotments. Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to allow eligible recipients to receive land allotments of up to 160 acres. Eligible recipients who previously received an allotment of less than 160 acres can now receive a parcel of Federal land under the Act of May 17, 1906, with a total area not exceeding the difference between 160 acres and the previous allotment size. This provision is in accordance with the amendments to Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows eligible recipients to file for an allotment within 3 years of regulations being promulgated. Allotments must be selected from vacant land owned by the United States. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows eligible recipients to select land from the United States. If the State of Alaska or a Native Corporation voluntarily relinquishes land for the allotment, they may choose equivalent Federal land as a replacement. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows eligible recipients to select land from the United States, excluding certain areas like the TransAlaska Pipeline right-of-way and National Park System units. The Shields v. United States case does not limit eligible allotment land. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows eligible recipients to choose alternative allotments from specific land areas, excluding National Park System units. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows eligible recipients to choose alternative allotments from specific land areas, excluding National Park System units. The Act also includes provisions for veterans who served during a specific period and for deceased individuals to have heirs apply for allotments on their behalf. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act prohibits individuals who have received or have pending allotments under the Act of May 17, 1906 from receiving allotments under this section, except for heirs applying on behalf of deceased persons and individuals who received allotments under the Act of May 17, 1906 with less than 160 acres before specific regulations were promulgated. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows for the approval of allotment applications within 5 years of enactment, with the Secretary issuing certificates of allotment under specified conditions. The Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act allows for private contests or protests against allotment applications within 90 days of receipt of the notice by the Secretary. The Secretary will not issue a certificate for an allotment until a final determination is made regarding private contests or protests. A person can reselect land if the originally selected land was chosen before the enactment of the Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act and was not conveyed to the person at the time of enactment. The term 'veteran' is defined as a person who served in the military. The term 'veteran' is defined as a person who served in the active military, naval, or air service and was discharged or released therefrom. The term 'Vietnam era' has a specific meaning as defined in title 38. The Secretary of the Interior will issue final regulations within a year of this Act's enactment, in consultation with Alaska Native organizations, to implement the amendments. Eligible individuals will be identified and contacted directly to explain the allotment application process.
